newsitem.title: EGYPT: Egypt's Mubarak urges end to bad view of Islam.
newsitem.headline: Egypt's Mubarak urges end to bad view of Islam.

text.p: Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak said in a speech on Sunday that Islam is seen as the West's main enemy in the post-Soviet era, and he urged Western countries to stop viewing Islam negatively.
Egypt's Minister of Religious Endowments Mahmoud Hamdi Zakzouk delivered Mubarak's speech at a conference in Cairo on Islam and the West.
"Some circles... since the collapse of the former Soviet union, regard Islam as the next threat and the substitute enemy for Western civilisation," Mubarak said.
"But the complexity of today's interests requires finding a common ground for cooperation among all peoples."

Delegates and ministers from more than 75 countries are attending the four-day "Islam and the West: Past, Present and Future" conference, which aims to promote dialogue about relations between Islamic countries and the West.
Mubarak said any effort to find common ground "...will be meaningless and will not continue unless the West stops viewing Islam negatively." He gave no specific examples.
In 1995, NATO secretary-general Willy Claes was quoted as saying Islamic fundamentalism posed as big a threat to the West as Communism once did.
In later interviews he moderated his tone, dropping the comparison with Communism but continuing to insist fundamentalism posed a major threat to the NATO alliance.
Islam is the official religion in Egypt, which sees itself as playing a pivotal role in Middle East peace brokering.

It hosts Islam's most prestigious seat of learning, the Cairo-based al-Azhar mosque. The head of Al-Azhar and Egypt's highest religious cleric, Sheikh Mohamed Sayyed Tantawi, told the conference that Moslems are required to fight those who fight Moslems and insult their prophet.
"We must extend a hand of peace to those who are in peace with us. But our religion orders us to fight those who fight us and insult prophets and our prophet," Tantawi said.
He did not mention the incident in June in which Palestinians in the West Bank city of Hebron found posters on shops depicting Islam's Prophet Mohammad as a pig.
Tantawi was quoted earlier this month as saying that the person who drew the posters must be killed.
A Jewish woman has been arrested and charged.
